prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: GRB Afterglow Millimeter Observations: Trigger 1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This is a proposal for target-of-opportunity observations of 5 Gamma-ray Burst afterglows to constrain the explosion energy, the circumburst density, and the nature of the progenitor environment. To maximize scientific return, we will only trigger on events with (i) optical/X-ray detections, (ii) redshift measurement, and (iii) cm-band detection with the JVLA within a day of the GRB discovery (the declination overlap range is -30 to +25 deg). To sample the mm light curve (and hence to extract the density profile) we request a total of 3 observations for each target at <5 days, 1-2 weeks, and 4-6 weeks. Since this is a continuum detection experiment of point sources at Band 3 (100 GHz), any tuning within band 3 and any array configuration will be suitable.

prj:VisitConstraint.prj:note: For each trigger, we will obtain 3 observations at < 5 days, 1-2 weeks, and 4-6 weeks.
For each trigger, we will obtain 3 observations at < 5 days, 1-2 weeks, and 4-6 weeks.
For each trigger, we will obtain 3 observations at < 5 days, 1-2 weeks, and 4-6 weeks.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: This is a continuum detection experiment. We request Band 3 to maximize sensitivity and minimize scheduling constraints due to observing conditions. Any spectral setup within Band 3 is suitable for our observations.
Our targets are point sources. Therefore any array configuration and angular resolution will be suitable for our observations.
We require a sensitivity of 25 uJy (RMS) to match the sensitivity of our JVLA observations and to track the millimeter light curve on the requisite timescale (4-6 weeks).

For maximum scientific return, in particular, to constrain the circumburst density profile of the GRB progenitor, we request our first observation within 5 days of requesting a trigger. We stress that about 20 GRBs are expected to pass our trigger criteria during cycle 3. Therefore even if the Array is not available for ToO observations 75% of the time when a trigger is requested, our science still remains feasible.
In our sequence of 3 observations for each ToO trigger, we would ideally like to execute the second and third observation for a given trigger only if the source is detected in the first observation. However, ALMA quality assurance and data delivery can take a month or longer and (according to the ALMA NAASC helpdesk) there is no mechanism in place (as of the Cycle 3 proposal deadline) to inform the PI within the relevant timescale whether the source is detected in the first epoch. Therefore we will request the full sequence of observations for each trigger, as feasible given ALMA scheduling constraints. For sources that are not detected in the individual epochs, we will utilize the data by stacking the observations, thereby placing deeper constraints on the mean flux density over the observing period.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) are the most luminous explosions in the Universe, and thus serve as unique laboratories for high-energy astrophysics and compact-object formation, as well as premier probes of the high-redshift universe. Observations of GRB "afterglows" can provide critical insight into the energy scale and local environment of the bursts, thereby shedding light on the explosion mechanism and nature of the progenitors. However, the existing extensive optical/X-ray afterglow data are degenerate with respect to these GRB properties. Millimeter and centimeter observations are critical for breaking these degeneracies, but pre-ALMA GRB follow-up has yielded a detection rate of <5%. With the advent of ALMA and the Jansky VLA we anticipate a renaissance in GRB studies, and here we request the first set of ALMA ToO observations of up to 5 GRBs (9.5 hours) to begin to address key unsolved questions. We will support the ALMA observations with our JVLA Large Program (218 hours), extensive optical follow-up (Gemini, Subaru, Magellan, MMT), and X-ray data (Swift, Chandra, XMM). To ensure a high detection rate we will only trigger ALMA observations for bursts first detected with the JVLA.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
